HELP_CALCULATING_INTEREST.CALCULATE_THIS: To calculate this, use the steps below.

EXAMPLE.ANNUAL_INTEREST: the annual interest would be £80 (1000 x 0.08 = 80) you’d divide £80 by 365 to get the daily interest: about 22p a day (80 / 365 = 0.22) after 50 days this would be £11 (50 x 0.22 = 11)

STEPS.DAILY_INTEREST: Work out the daily interest: divide your yearly interest from step 1 by 365 (the number of days in a year).
STEPS.TOTAL_INTEREST: Work out the total amount of interest: multiply the daily interest from step 2 by the number of days the debt has been overdue.
STEPS.YEARLY_INTEREST: Work out the yearly interest: take the amount you’re claiming and multiply it by 0.08 (which is 8%).

HELP_CALCULATING_INTEREST.TITLE: Help calculating interest
HELP_CALCULATING_INTEREST.USUAL_RATE: For most types of debt the rate is usually 8%.

DETAILS.TITLE: What is Disclosure?
DETAILS.PARAGRAPH1: You are required to share (disclose) all documents which are relevant to the claim with all parties involved.
DETAILS.PARAGRAPH2: This includes all physical and electronic documents, such as invoices and contracts, as well as images, videos, text messages, and social media messages.
DETAILS.PARAGRAPH3: You must disclose all relevant documents, even if you do not intend to rely on them during a hearing or if they are harmful to your claim.
DETAILS.PARAGRAPH4: A list of documents from the other parties will be made available to you, and you can ask for copies of any of these documents. The other parties involved in the claim can also ask to see and inspect copies of documents you disclose.

DETAILS.PARAGRAPH1: Parties can agree ahead of time what electronic documents will be disclosed by all parties involved in the claim.

WHAT_ARE_FIXED_RECOVERABLE_COSTS.TITLE: What are Fixed Recoverable Costs?
WHAT_ARE_FIXED_RECOVERABLE_COSTS.PARA_1: Most civil money claims valued up to and including £100,000 are subject to the Fixed Recoverable Costs Regime (FRCs).
WHAT_ARE_FIXED_RECOVERABLE_COSTS.PARA_2: FRCs set limits on the amount of legal costs the successful parties can claim back from the unsuccessful parties.
WHAT_ARE_FIXED_RECOVERABLE_COSTS.PARA_3: They provide certainty to all parties involved by setting in advance the maximum amount of costs the losing party will have to pay.

URL.BEFORE: See Table 14 in the Civil Procedure Rules for
URL.TEXT: more information on limits for FRCs (opens in new tab)

WHAT_ARE_FIXED_RECOVERABLE_COSTS.PARA_4: All claims subject to FRCs need to be assigned to a complexity band from 1 to 4.
WHAT_ARE_FIXED_RECOVERABLE_COSTS.PARA_5_2: claims where only one issue is in dispute
WHAT_ARE_FIXED_RECOVERABLE_COSTS.PARA_5_3: For example, claims where either the amount of money being claimed, or liability (legal responsibility) is in dispute.
WHAT_ARE_FIXED_RECOVERABLE_COSTS.PARA_6_2: where more than one issue is in dispute
WHAT_ARE_FIXED_RECOVERABLE_COSTS.PARA_6_3: For example, the amount of money being claimed, and liability is in dispute.
WHAT_ARE_FIXED_RECOVERABLE_COSTS.PARA_7_2: more than one issue is in dispute
WHAT_ARE_FIXED_RECOVERABLE_COSTS.PARA_7_3: For example, noise induced hearing loss or employer liability for diseases.
WHAT_ARE_FIXED_RECOVERABLE_COSTS.PARA_8_2: serious issues around the facts of law
WHAT_ARE_FIXED_RECOVERABLE_COSTS.PARA_9: How is the complexity band decided?
WHAT_ARE_FIXED_RECOVERABLE_COSTS.PARA_9_1: You may agree the complexity band with the other parties beforehand or say which band you think this claim falls into.
WHAT_ARE_FIXED_RECOVERABLE_COSTS.PARA_10: However, if the Court disagrees, it has the power to assign a claim to whatever band it feels is appropriate.

WHICH_COMPLEXITY_BAND_TO_CHOOSE.TITLE: Which complexity band should I use?
WHICH_COMPLEXITY_BAND_TO_CHOOSE.PARA_1: Any claim where only one issue is in dispute. For example, claims where only the amount of money, or liability (legal responsibility) is in dispute. Examples include:
WHICH_COMPLEXITY_BAND_TO_CHOOSE.PARA_1_POINT_1: Personal injury claims where liability or the amount of money being claimed is disputed.
WHICH_COMPLEXITY_BAND_TO_CHOOSE.PARA_1_POINT_2: Road traffic accidents with no claim for personal injury.
WHICH_COMPLEXITY_BAND_TO_CHOOSE.PARA_1_POINT_3: Debt claims where there is disagreement over the facts of the claim.
WHICH_COMPLEXITY_BAND_TO_CHOOSE.PARA_2: Most claims where more than one issue is in dispute. For example, claims where the amount of money being claimed, and liability (legal responsibility) is in dispute. Examples include:
WHICH_COMPLEXITY_BAND_TO_CHOOSE.PARA_2_POINT_1: Personal injury claims where liability and the amount of money being claimed is disputed.
WHICH_COMPLEXITY_BAND_TO_CHOOSE.PARA_2_POINT_2: Road traffic accidents which include a claim for personal injury.
WHICH_COMPLEXITY_BAND_TO_CHOOSE.PARA_3: Any other claims where more than one issue is in dispute. For example:
WHICH_COMPLEXITY_BAND_TO_CHOOSE.PARA_4: Any claim which is not suitable for bands 1 to 3. For example:
WHICH_COMPLEXITY_BAND_TO_CHOOSE.PARA_4_POINT_1: Complex personal injury claims with serious issues around the facts or law.

URL.TITLE: For more information on complexity bands
URL.BEFORE: For more information on complexity bands see
URL.TEXT: CPR 26.16 Table 2 (opens in a new tab)

ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_AS_2_CARM: This service allows you to make a money claim against an individual or an organisation for £25,000 or less.
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_AS_3: This website is run by HM Courts and Tribunals Services (HMCTS). We want as many people as possible to be able to use this website. For example, you should be able to:
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_AS_4: change colours, contrast levels and fonts
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_AS_5: zoom in up to 300% without the text spilling off the screen
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_AS_6: navigate most of the website using just a keyboard
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_AS_7: navigate most of the website using speech recognition software
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_AS_8: listen to most of the website using a screen reader (including the most recent version of VoiceOver)
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_AS_9: We’ve also made the website text as simple as possible to understand.
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_AS_10: has advice on making your device easier to use if you have a disability.
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_COMPLIANCE_2: This website is partially compliant with the
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_COMPLIANCE_4: AA standard, due to the non-compliances listed below.
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_CONTACTING_1: Contacting us by phone or visiting us in person
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_CONTACTING_2: We provide a text relay service for people who are D/deaf, hearing impaired or have a speech impediment.
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_CONTACTING_3: Our offices have audio induction loops, or if you contact us before your visit, we can arrange a British Sign Language (BSL) interpreter.
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_CONTACTING_4: Find out how to contact us using the contact details above.
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_ENFORCEMENT_2: The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the ‘accessibility regulations’). If you’re not happy with how we respond to your complaint,
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_ENFORCEMENT_3: contact the Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS)
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_FEEDBACK_2: If you need information on this website in a different format like accessible PDF, large print, easy read, audio recording or braille:
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_FEEDBACK_3: If you plan to visit our office and need support, such as a British Sign Language (BSL) interpreter or assistance with our audio induction loops, please contact us in advance.

ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_FEEDBACK_5: For in-person visits or if you need information on this website in a different format, such as an accessible PDF, large print, easy read, audio recording or braille, reach out to us at:
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_HOW_2: We know some parts of this service are not fully accessible:
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_HOW_2_CARM: We know some parts of this service are not fully accessible. The digital service is accessible and meets the WCAG 2.2 AA standard. However, some features are not accessible because:
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_HOW_3: Error messages are not specific to the field where the error was made.
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_HOW_4: The tabbing order on some pages do not map to the visual order.
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_HOW_5: The feedback link is not contextually clear that it will open in another tab.
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_IMPROVE_1: What we’re doing to improve accessibility
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_IMPROVE_2: We continually run automated accessibility testing as part of our development practices. This helps us to resolve issues before we launch new pages or features.
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_IMPROVE_3: This website will also be tested by the Digital Accessibility Centre (DAC) in late 2024.
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_IMPROVE_4: We plan to fix these issues by early 2025.
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_IMPROVE_5: We continually run automated accessibility testing as part of our development practices. This helps us to resolve issues before we launch new pages or features.
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_IMPROVE_6: This website will also be tested by the Digital Accessibility Centre (DAC) in late 2024.
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_NON_ACCESIBLE_2: The content listed below is non-accessible for the following reasons.
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_NON_ACCESIBLE_5: Screen reader users might have difficulty navigating error messages as some error messages are not specific to the field where the error was made. This fails Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.2 [3.3.1] success criterion (Error Identification). We plan to fix this by late 2024.
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_NON_ACCESIBLE_6: Screen reader users might have difficulty navigating error messages as some error messages are not specific to the field where the error was made. This fails WCAG 2.2 [3.3.1] success criterion (Error Identification).
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_NON_ACCESIBLE_7: Screen reader/Keyboard users might have difficulty navigating the screen where they are required to provide unavailable dates as the remove button is not visually present but appears in the tabbing order. This fails WCAG 2.4.2 success criterion (Focus order).
ACCESSIBILITY_STATEMENT.PARAGRAPH_NON_ACCESIBLE_8: Opening the ‘feedback’ link causes users to move to a new tab without warning. This may be confusing for screen reader users who may be unaware that they have moved to a new tab. This fails WCAG 2.4.6 success criterion (Link Purpose (In Context)).

PRIVACY_POLICY.TITLE: Privacy policy
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_1: This privacy policy explains why we collect your personal data and what we do with it. It also explains your rights and how to enforce them.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_3: This service is managed by HM Courts and Tribunals Service (HMCTS), which is an executive agency of the Ministry of Justice (MoJ).
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_4: The MoJ is known as the data controller for data protection purposes. The
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_6: explains how the MoJ processes personal data.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_7: As part of the MoJ, HMCTS is responsible for deciding how your personal data is used and for protecting the personal data you provide.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_8: More information about how to use the service is in the
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_9: Why we collect your personal data
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_10: We collect your personal data to:
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_14: Our staff use your personal data to process your claim or application. They work in the UK and your data is stored in the UK.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_15: Types of personal data we collect
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_16: The personal data we collect includes:
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_17: your name, address and contact details
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_18: your email and password (if you create an account)
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_19: other personal information you provide in your claim or application
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_21: As part of your claim you’ll be asked to use your email address to set up an account. You will be able to use this email and password to sign into other HMCTS services.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_22: We may ask for your permission to use your email address to send you emails using GOV.UK Notify. This system processes emails only within the European Economic Area until the point where emails are handed over to the email provider you use.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_24: to collect data that tells us about how you’re using this service, including:
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_25: if you open an email from us or click on a link in an email
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_26: your computer, phone or tablet’s IP address
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_27: the region or town where you are using your computer, phone or tablet
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_30: While processing your claim or application, another government department, agency or organisation might be involved and we may share your data with them.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_31: Any data posted in by you or other parties to support the claim issue and progression will be shared with Exela Technologies Limited and, if printing is required, with Xerox (UK) Ltd.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_32: If you contact us and ask for help with the service you are using, your personal data may be shared with the Good Things Foundation. This is a company who we have partnered with to offer face to face support.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_33: In some circumstances we may share your data for example, to prevent or detect crime, or to produce anonymised statistics.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_34: We use Google Analytics to collect data about how a website is used. This anonymous data is shared with Google. Find out about this in our
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_35: The information you submit will be shared with everyone who is named on the claim. This excludes any payment details that you use to pay court fees.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_36: If a judgment is made on a case some information is shared with Registry Trust Limited who provide financial information about court judgments to banks and credit agencies.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_37: Storing and sharing your data internationally
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_38: Sometimes we need to send your personal information outside of the UK. When we do this we comply with data protection law.

PRIVACY_POLICY.P_69: If you are using the money claims service we may ask you for:
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_71: your business or organisation if you are acting on their behalf

PRIVACY_POLICY.P_81: If you are responding to a money claim we ask you to check the personal information about you that was provided by the claimant which includes your name, your address and contact details.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_82: We may ask you to provide:
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_84: your business or organisation if you are acting on their behalf
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_85: your response to the claim made against you
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_86: the timeline of events leading to the dispute
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_87: a list of any evidence you have to support your claim
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_89: When you use this service you’ll be asked to use your email address to set up an account. You can use this email and password to sign into other HMCTS services.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_91: The information you enter in the money claims service is saved until you decide to submit it. This allows you to save what you are doing and continue later. Saved information that you do not submit will be deleted after 90 days.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_93: The information you submit for a money claim will be deleted 2 years after the court makes a decision on the outcome of your claim (this is called a judgment).
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_94: If the court doesn’t make a decision about your claim (for example, you settle the claim out of court and a judgment is no longer required) then the information you provide will be deleted 3 years after the last update made to the claim.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_96: In the course of carrying out various functions, HMCTS creates and holds a wide range of recorded information. Records will be properly retained to enable HMCTS to meet its business needs, legal requirements, to evidence events or agreements in the event of allegations or disputes and to ensure that any records of historic value are preserved.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_97: The untimely destruction of records could affect the conduct of HMCTS business and HMCTS ability to comply with statutory obligations. Conversely, the permanent retention of records is undesirable and disposal is necessary to free up storage space, reduce administrative burden and to ensure that HMCTS does not unlawfully retain records for longer than necessary (particularly those containing personal data).
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_98: 1. This policy supports HMCTS in demonstrating accountability through the proper retention of records and by demonstrating that disposal decisions are taken with proper authority and in accordance with due process.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_99: 2. The purpose of this policy is to provide guidance as to set out the length of time that HMCTS records should be retained and the processes to review the records as to any further retention or for disposing of records at the end of the retention period. The policy helps to ensure that HMCTS operates in compliance with the General Data Protection Regulation and any other legislative or regulatory retention obligations.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_100: 3. The policy covers the records listed by HMCTS irrespective of the media on which they are created or held including:
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_102: electronic files (including database, Word documents, power point presentations, spreadsheets, webpages and e-mails)
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_103: photographs, scanned images, CD-ROMs and video tapes
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_104: And includes all types of records which HMCTS creates or holds on behalf of the members. The records may include, but are not limited to, the following:
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_111: 4. The retention period for records is six years, unless the following applies:
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_112: If the case has been transferred to a County Court the record will be copied to a paper file, in which case the electronic record will be destroyed after three years
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_113: HMCTS has the ability to change the date the file will be disposed of if, for example, a caseworker reviews the file and notes that after six years the case is still progressing. In these circumstances the date of disposal will be extended for a minimum of one year.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_114: 5. The Data Protection Manager is responsible for ensuring that the user information is periodically reviewed (annually) to determine whether any retention periods have expired. Once the retention period has expired, the record must be reviewed and a ‘disposal action’ agreed upon. A ‘disposal action’ is;
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_115: the destruction of the record; or
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_116: the retention of the record for a further period under the instruction from the Data Controller of the data
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_117: 6. No destruction of a record will take place without assurance that:
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_118: the record is no longer required by HMCTS
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_119: no litigation or investigation is current or pending which affects the claim
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_120: there are no current or pending FOIA or GDPR subject access requests which affect the record.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_121: 6.1 Destruction of Paper Records. Destruction will be carried out in a way that preserves the confidentiality of the record. Non-confidential records will be placed in ordinary rubbish bins or recycling bins. Confidential records will be placed in confidential waste bins and collected by the Chambers approved disposal firm for secure destruction. A certificate of destruction will be provided upon each completed process. All copies including security copies, preservation copies and backup copies will also be destroyed at the same time in the same manner.
PRIVACY_POLICY.P_122: 6.2 Destruction of Electronic Records. All electronic records will be either physically destroyed or wiped. Confirmation of the date of this will be recorded by HMCTS.

START_PAGE.YOU_DID_NOT_ATTEND: You did not attend your mediation appointment. The judge may order you to pay costs or may automatically rule in the other party’s favour.
START_PAGE.IF_YOU_WERE_UNABLE: If you were unable to attend mediation due to exceptional circumstances, you can explain why with supporting evidence, such as a doctor’s note or photographs of relevant documents. This is sometimes known as filing a representation. If the judge accepts your reasons for non-attendance, you will not be issued with a penalty.
START_PAGE.YOU_CANNOT_WITHDRAW: You cannot withdraw a document once you have submitted it. If you want to add more information to something you have already submitted, you can upload the document again. You should add a version number to the name, for example, ‘version 2’.
START_PAGE.THE_OTHER_PARTIES: The other parties will be able to see the documents you have uploaded and you will be able to see their documents.
START_PAGE.YOU_HAVE_UNTIL: You have until 14 days before your hearing to submit documents.
START_PAGE.YOU_DO_NOT_HAVE: You do not have to upload all your documents at once. You can return to upload them later.
START_PAGE.BEFORE YOU UPLOAD: Before you upload your document, give it a name that tells the court what it is, for example “Mediation non-attendance statement by Jane Smith”
START_PAGE.EACH_DOCUMENT_MUST: Each document must be less than 100MB. You can upload the following file types: DOC/DOCX (Word), XLS/XLSX (Excel), PPT/PPTX (PowerPoint), PDF, RTF, TXT, CSV, JPG/JPEG, PNG, BMP, TIF/TIFF.
START_PAGE.EACH_DOCUMENT_MUST_WITH_SAVE_FILE: Each document must be less than 100MB. You can upload the following file types: DOC/DOCX (Word), XLS/XLSX (Excel), PPT/PPTX (PowerPoint), PDF, RTF, TXT, CSV, JPG/JPEG, PNG, BMP, TIF/TIFF. After choosing the file, click 'save file'.

UNAVAILABILITY_SELECT_DATES_MEDIATION.PAGE_TEXT: Add a single date or longer period of time that you cannot attend mediation
UNAVAILABILITY_SELECT_DATES_MEDIATION.PAGE_HINT_TEXT1: Provide all dates in the next 3 months when you cannot attend a mediation appointment as accurately as you can. Once a date for your appointment has been set, it can be difficult to re-arrange.
UNAVAILABILITY_SELECT_DATES_MEDIATION.PAGE_HINT_TEXT2: The Small claims Mediation Service operates Monday to Friday, 8am to 5pm, except bank holidays.

UNAVAILABILITY_NEXT_THREE_MONTHS_MEDIATI.PAGE_TEXT: Are there any dates in the next 3 months when you cannot attend mediation?
UNAVAILABILITY_NEXT_THREE_MONTHS_MEDIATI.PAGE_HINT_TEXT: These should only be the dates of important events like medical appointments, other court hearings, or holidays you're already booked. If you do not attend your appointment, you may face a penalty.

MEDIATION_PHONE_CONFIRMATION.PAGE_TEXT: Can the mediator use {{ partyPhone }} to call you for your mediation appointment?

TELEPHONE_FOR_MEDIATION.YOU_WISH_TO_PROCEED_WITH_THE_CLAIM: You wish to proceed with the claim. The next step is mediation.
TELEPHONE_FOR_MEDIATION.IF_THE_CLAIMANT_DISAGREES: If the claimant disagrees with your response, you must take part in mediation.
TELEPHONE_FOR_MEDIATION.A_TELEPHONE_MEDIATION_APPOINTMENT: A telephone mediation appointment will be scheduled at no additional cost.
TELEPHONE_FOR_MEDIATION.AN_IMPARTIAL_MEDIATOR: An impartial mediator will speak with both parties to see if an agreement can be reached before the case goes to court. You will be able to explain your reasons for rejecting the claim in more detail.
TELEPHONE_FOR_MEDIATION.MEDIATION_WILL_LAST: Mediation will last no longer than one hour and will take place by telephone.
TELEPHONE_FOR_MEDIATION.WE_WILL_ARRANGE: We will arrange a phone call with a mediator from the Small Claims Mediation Service. The mediator will:
TELEPHONE_FOR_MEDIATION.BULLET_LIST_ITEM1: listen to each side separately – you will not talk directly to the other side
TELEPHONE_FOR_MEDIATION.BULLET_LIST_ITEM2: ask you to consider what the other side says
TELEPHONE_FOR_MEDIATION.BULLET_LIST_ITEM3: help you reach an agreement, if possible
TELEPHONE_FOR_MEDIATION.WHAT_HAPPENS_IF: What happens if you do not attend your mediation appointment?
TELEPHONE_FOR_MEDIATION.IF_YOU_DO_NOT_ATTEND: If you do not attend your mediation appointment, the judge may apply a penalty. This could include the judge automatically ruling in the other party’s favour, or paying for some or all of the other party’s costs.
TELEPHONE_FOR_MEDIATION.IF_MEDIATION_IS_SUCCESSFUL: If mediation is successful, you will not have to go to court. You will make an agreement over the phone, which we will email to you. You will not have to sign anything, but the agreement is binding.
TELEPHONE_FOR_MEDIATION.IF_EITHER_PARTY: If either party breaks the terms of the agreement, the other party can go back to the court to ask for a judgment or hearing.
TELEPHONE_FOR_MEDIATION.IF_YOU_DO_NOT_REACH: If you do not reach an agreement at mediation, you may need to attend a court hearing. Any mediation discussions cannot be mentioned at the hearing.

CITIZEN_RESPONSE_TYPE.ACCEPT_OR_TRANSFER: They can accept the amount you've paid and settle the claim, or ask the court to transfer the claim to a County Court hearing centre.
CITIZEN_RESPONSE_TYPE.ADMIT_ALL_CANT_PAY: If you admit all of the claim but can't pay immediately, you can offer to pay the claimant in instalments.
CITIZEN_RESPONSE_TYPE.ADMIT_ALL_DEADLINE: You have until 4pm on {{ deadline }} to admit the claim.
CITIZEN_RESPONSE_TYPE.AGAINST_INDIVIDUAL: If the claim is against you as an individual, the hearing centre will be the nearest one to your home or business.
CITIZEN_RESPONSE_TYPE.CLAIMANT_ACCEPT_OFFER: If the claimant accepts your offer, they can ask the court to enter a CCJ against you and you'll be sent an order to pay.
CITIZEN_RESPONSE_TYPE.CLAIMANT_ACCEPT_PART_ADMISSION: If the claimant accepts your part-admission and you can't pay immediately, you can offer to pay in instalments.
CITIZEN_RESPONSE_TYPE.CLAIMANT_AGREES: If the claimant agrees, they can ask court to enter a CCJ against you and you'll be sent an order to pay.
CITIZEN_RESPONSE_TYPE.CLAIMANT_INDIVIDUAL: If the claimant is an individual and the claim is against you as an organisation, the hearing centre will be the nearest one to their home or business.
CITIZEN_RESPONSE_TYPE.CLAIMANT_RECEIPT: You should ask the claimant to give you a receipt.
CITIZEN_RESPONSE_TYPE.CLAIMANT_REJECT_OFFER: If the claimant rejects your offer, they can ask the court to enter a CCJ against you. The court will then decide the repayment plan.
CITIZEN_RESPONSE_TYPE.CLAIMANT_REJECT_PART_ADMISSION: If they reject your offer, the court will decide a repayment plan.
CITIZEN_RESPONSE_TYPE.COUNTER_CLAIM: Reject all of the claim and counterclaim
CITIZEN_RESPONSE_TYPE.FULL_ADMISSION: I admit all of the claim
CITIZEN_RESPONSE_TYPE.FULL_ADMISSION_HINT: You agree you owe the full amount claimed.
CITIZEN_RESPONSE_TYPE.FULL_DEFENCE_HINT: You've either paid what you believe you owe or you reject the claim.
CITIZEN_RESPONSE_TYPE.HOW_DO_YOU_RESPOND: How do you respond to the claim?

CLAIMANT_FORMALISE_REPAYMENT_TYPE.WARNING_TEXT: For a period, the settlement agreement will not be available. Both parties can still have a signed agreement which can be sent to the court at contactocmc@justice.gov.uk. The court will also accept the claimant’s confirmation that an agreement has been reached. Any agreement confirmed with the court will stay the claim with the claimant able to apply for Judgment by using form N225: Ask for judgment on a claim for a specified amount of money - GOV.UK if the defendant fully admitted or Notice of part admission (Specified amount): Form N225A - GOV.UK for part admission, if the agreement breaks down and the form should be sent to contactocmc@justice.gov.uk. If after 6 months from the agreement the claimant has not requested a Judgment, if an agreement has broken down, then an application will need to be made to lift the stay, using form Make an application to a court (application notice): Form N244 - GOV.UK, which should be sent to contactocmc@justice.gov.uk

DISCLOSURE_OF_DOCUMENTS.TITLE: Disclosure of documents
DISCLOSURE_OF_DOCUMENTS.CHECKBOX_TITLE: You can ask the court to order disclosure of documents from the other parties. Do you want to request the disclosure of electronic or non-electronic documents, or both? (optional)
DISCLOSURE_OF_DOCUMENTS.WHAT_IS_THE_DIFFERENCE: What is the difference between electronic and non-electronic documents?
DISCLOSURE_OF_DOCUMENTS.PARAGRAPH_1.1: Electronic documents are any documents that can be supplied in any digital or electronic format. This includes physical documents which can be supplied in an electronic format.
DISCLOSURE_OF_DOCUMENTS.PARAGRAPH_1.2: These formats include DOC/DOCX (Word), XLS/XLSX (Excel), PPT/PPTX (PowerPoint), PDF, RTF, TXT, CSV, JPG/JPEG, PNG, BMP, TIF/TIFF.
DISCLOSURE_OF_DOCUMENTS.PARAGRAPH_1.3: For example, an invoice or contract which was a physical document, but has been scanned or photographed and can be submitted electronically is an electronic document.
DISCLOSURE_OF_DOCUMENTS.PARAGRAPH_2.1: Non-electronic documents are physical documents which are not in a digital or electronic format. This includes electronic documents, which happen to be in a physical format.
DISCLOSURE_OF_DOCUMENTS.PARAGRAPH_2.2: For example, a print-out of an email is a non-electronic document.

INFORM_THE_COURT_OF_A_BREATHING_SPACE.HOW_TO_CONTACT_PARA1: If you have not yet received a directions order then you should contact the Courts and Tribunal Service Centre (CTSC):

INFORM_THE_COURT_OF_A_BREATHING_SPACE.SUMMARY: The Debt Respite Scheme (Breathing Space) gives someone in problem debt the right to legal protection from their creditors.
INFORM_THE_COURT_OF_A_BREATHING_SPACE.WHAT_NEXT: What you need to do now
INFORM_THE_COURT_OF_A_BREATHING_SPACE.WHAT_NEXT_PARAGRAPH_1: If you’re notified by the Insolvency Service that a debt owed to you is in a breathing space, you must inform the court by email or post. You must tell the court about each debt that has entered a breathing space.
INFORM_THE_COURT_OF_A_BREATHING_SPACE.WHAT_NEXT_PARAGRAPH_2: The court will not check for other debts against the debtor’s name. If the debtor has debts owed to you at different courts, you must notify each court.
INFORM_THE_COURT_OF_A_BREATHING_SPACE.WHAT_NEXT_PARAGRAPH_3: When informing the court, you must state:
INFORM_THE_COURT_OF_A_BREATHING_SPACE.WHAT_NEXT_PARAGRAPH_4: You can find this information in the notification you received from the Insolvency Service. You will also need to provide the court claim number.
INFORM_THE_COURT_OF_A_BREATHING_SPACE.WHAT_HAPPENS_DURING_BS_PARA1: Court orders and judgments related to a debt which were made before breathing space started cannot be enforced until the breathing space ends unless the court gives permission to continue.
INFORM_THE_COURT_OF_A_BREATHING_SPACE.WHAT_HAPPENS_DURING_BS_PARA2: If a hearing has been scheduled then this may be cancelled while the breathing space is in place.

DETAILS.FIRST_PARAGRAPH: This agreement settles the claim made by {{ claimant }} against {{ defendant }}. This includes all money owed in the claim, for example court fees, expenses or interest.
DETAILS.NO: No - I reject the terms of the agreement.
DETAILS.ON_HOLD: The claim will be put on hold and the claimant can't request a CCJ against you.
DETAILS.REQUEST_CCJ: The claimant can request a CCJ against you to enforce the repayment plan shown in the agreement. You can ask a judge to change the plan based on your financial details. The court has reviewed the plan and believes you can afford it, so a judge may not change it.
DETAILS.SECOND_PARAGRAPH: Neither party can make any further claims relating to this case, other than to enforce it.

ELIGIBILITY_USEFUL_INFO_FEES.CONTINUE_HELP_WITH_FEES: Do you wish to continue to make a Help with Fees Application?
ELIGIBILITY_USEFUL_INFO_FEES.HELP_WITH_FEES: If you want to apply for Help with Fees, you will complete an online form in a new window. This will give you a reference number. Please note the number and keep it safe, as you will need it later in the claim process. (NB: if you have more than one claim going on, each claim must have a separate Help with Fees application and reference number). You can send in your claim as soon as you have the Help with Fees reference number, but the claim will not be issued until the Help with Fees application has been processed by the court. This is so that you will know what fees are covered and what you still have to pay. If you choose not to pay, the claim will not be issued.
ELIGIBILITY_USEFUL_INFO_FEES.HELP_WITH_FEES_ADVICE: You may be asked by the court to email evidence in support of your application before your claim is issued.
ELIGIBILITY_USEFUL_INFO_FEES.HELP_WITH_FEES_INTRO: Making an application for Help with Fees does not guarantee that you will get your fee covered. You may still have to pay some or all your court fee to get the claim issued (for the court system to officially start the claim and send details to the other side). When you apply for Help with Fees, we aim to provide an update within 5- 10 working days.
ELIGIBILITY_USEFUL_INFO_FEES.TITLE: Some useful information about Help with Fees

EXPERT_DETAILS.TELL_US_WHY_NEED_EXPERT: Tell us why you need this expert

EXPERT_GUIDANCE.ASK_PERMISSION: You must ask for permission to use an expert - a judge will then decide whether the expert is necessary.
EXPERT_GUIDANCE.COST_HIRING_EXPERT: The cost of hiring an expert depends on which expert you and the other party choose.
EXPERT_GUIDANCE.EXPERT_REPORT: The expert will provide a written report - they won't usually come to court in person.
EXPERT_GUIDANCE.FOR_EXAMPLE: For example, they might allow a structural engineer to be used in a claim about building works or a mechanic in a claim about car repairs.
EXPERT_GUIDANCE.IF_JUDGE_ALLOWS: If a judge allows you to use an expert, you'll usually have to share one expert with the other party.
EXPERT_GUIDANCE.IF_PERMISSION: If you get permission to use an expert
EXPERT_GUIDANCE.IF_YOU_WIN: If you win the case you may be able to recover a maximum of £750 of the cost you paid. A judge will rule on this at the end of the hearing.
EXPERT_GUIDANCE.JUDGE_ALLOW_EXPERT: A judge will only allow you to use an expert if they believe they need the expert's specialist knowledge.
EXPERT_GUIDANCE.JUDGE_DECIDE_COST: The judge will also decide whether the cost of the expert is reasonable compared to the value of the claim.
EXPERT_GUIDANCE.JUDGE_MAY_ASK: The judge may ask one of you to make a list of 3 independent experts who can provide a written report in return for a fee.
EXPERT_GUIDANCE.JUDGES_RESPONSIBLE_COST: Even though you and the other party share the cost of hiring the expert, judges are still responsible for keeping costs in proportion to value.
EXPERT_GUIDANCE.MUST_AVOID_DISCUSSING: You must avoid discussing the case in detail with the 3 experts.
EXPERT_GUIDANCE.OTHER_PARTY_CHOOSES: The other party then chooses one expert from the list. After that, you both need to follow these steps

FIRST_CONTACT_SIGNPOSTING.TITLE: Respond to a money claim
FIRST_CONTACT_SIGNPOSTING.PARAGRAPH_1: To find the deadline date that you need to respond by refer to the letter or email you received explaining the claim. The response deadline will also be shown when you create and or login to your account.
FIRST_CONTACT_SIGNPOSTING.PARAGRAPH_3: We'll send your response to the claimant (the person or organisation who says you owe them money).
FIRST_CONTACT_SIGNPOSTING.PARAGRAPH_4_PART_1: The claimant can apply for a
FIRST_CONTACT_SIGNPOSTING.PARAGRAPH_4_PART_2: against you if you don't respond before the deadline.
FIRST_CONTACT_SIGNPOSTING.PARAGRAPH_5: They can use a CCJ to get the money from you, for example by applying to the court to send bailiffs to your home or business.
FIRST_CONTACT_SIGNPOSTING.PARAGRAPH_6: A CCJ may make it harder to get credit, such as a mobile phone contract, credit card or mortgage.

FREE_TELEPHONE_MEDIATION.AUTOMATICALLY_REGISTERED: We have automatically registered you for free telephone mediation from HM Courts and Tribunals Service.
FREE_TELEPHONE_MEDIATION.CLAIMANT_MUST_AGREE: The claimant must agree to mediation. We'll contact you within 28 days after the claimant's confirmation, to arrange a free appointment.
FREE_TELEPHONE_MEDIATION.DO_NOT_AGREE_TO_FREE_MEDIATION: I do not agree to free mediation
FREE_TELEPHONE_MEDIATION.EITHER_PARTY_BREAKS_TERMS: If either party breaks the terms the other party can go to court to ask for a judgment or hearing.
FREE_TELEPHONE_MEDIATION.LAST_LESS_AN_HOUR: Your mediation appointment will last for no more than an hour.
FREE_TELEPHONE_MEDIATION.MEDIATION_SUCCESSFUL: If mediation is successful, you'll make a verbal agreement over the phone. This is legally binding which means that you must comply with it. You will be given the terms of the agreement in a document – this is called a settlement agreement.
FREE_TELEPHONE_MEDIATION.MEDIATION_IS_CONFIDENTIAL: Mediation is confidential, and nothing said in the mediation can be used in court proceedings if the dispute cannot be settled. The mediator speaks to each party separately, this is not a conference call.
FREE_TELEPHONE_MEDIATION.MEDIATION_FAILS: If mediation fails and a court hearing is needed, what happened during the mediation appointment cannot be mentioned in court.
FREE_TELEPHONE_MEDIATION.MEDIATION_QUICKER: Mediation can be quicker, cheaper and less stressful than going to court.
FREE_TELEPHONE_MEDIATION.NO_AGREE: I do not agree to free mediation
FREE_TELEPHONE_MEDIATION.NEUTRAL_MEDIATOR_LISTEN: A trained, neutral mediator from HM Courts and Tribunals Service will listen to your views and help you to negotiate a settlement of your dispute.
FREE_TELEPHONE_MEDIATION.NO_WAIT_COURT_HEARING: You will not have to wait longer for a court hearing if you choose mediation.
FREE_TELEPHONE_MEDIATION.OPENS_IN_NEW_TAB: free telephone mediation (opens in new tab).

SELECTED_APPLICATION_TYPE.IMPOSE_SANCTION: Court to impose a sanction on the other parties unless they do a specific action
SELECTED_APPLICATION_TYPE.MORE_TIME: More time to do what is required by a court order
SELECTED_APPLICATION_TYPE.NOT_ON_LIST: Court to do something that's not on this list
SELECTED_APPLICATION_TYPE.RELIEF_PENALTY: Relief from a penalty you've been given by the court
SELECTED_APPLICATION_TYPE.SETTLING: Court to make an order settling the claim by consent
SELECTED_APPLICATION_TYPE.STRIKE_OUT: Court to strike out all or part of the other parties' case without a trial

SELECT_TYPE.APPLICATION_NOT_NEW: An application is not a new claim. It is a request for a judge to take an action on an existing claim.
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_CANCEL_JUDGMENT: Ask to set aside (cancel) a judgment
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_CANCEL_JUDGMENT_DESCRIPTION: For example, if you do not believe a judgment should've been made or you've not had the opportunity to respond to a claim and you have a defence. This application is usually made by defendants.
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_CHANGE_CLAIM: Ask to make a change to your claim or defence that you've submitted
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_CHANGE_CLAIM_DESCRIPTION: This is also known as an application to amend a statement of case.
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_CHANGE_HEARING: Ask to change a hearing date
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_CHANGE_HEARING_DESCRIPTION: This is also known as an application to adjourn a hearing.
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_DO_SOMETHING: Ask the court to do something that's not on this list
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_DO_SOMETHING_DESCRIPTION: Select this option if you cannot see the application you want on this list.
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_IMPOSE_SANCTION: Ask the court to impose a sanction on the other parties unless they do a specific action
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_IMPOSE_SANCTION_DESCRIPTION: For example. striking out their claim or defence unless they upload all their documents by a specific date. This is also known as an application for an unless order.
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_MORE_TIME: Ask for more time to do what is required by a court order
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_MORE_TIME_DESCRIPTION_1: For example, asking for the deadline for uploading documents before a trial or hearing to be extended. You'll need to provide a valid reason for not meeting the original deadline. This application can only be made before the original deadline has passed. This is also known as an application to extend time.
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_MORE_TIME_DESCRIPTION_2: Instead of making an application, you can get written agreement from the other parties for more time to do what's required by the court. To do this, the time extension you request must be less than 28 days and should not affect a hearing date.
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_PAUSE: Ask the court to pause a claim
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_PAUSE_DESCRIPTION: This is also known as an application to stay the claim.
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_RECONSIDER: Ask the court to reconsider an order
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_RECONSIDER_DESCRIPTION: If an order has been made after an application or a hearing that you were not informed about. This is also known as an application to set aside or vary an order.
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_RELIEF_PENALTY: Ask for relief from a penalty you've been given by the court
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_RELIEF_PENALTY_DESCRIPTION: For example, if you have not uploaded documents by the deadline. You can only make this application after the penalty has been given. This is also known as an application for relief from sanctions.
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_SETTLING: Ask the court to make an order settling the claim by consent
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_SETTLING_DESCRIPTION: The other parties must have agreed to this application. If there's a hearing date already scheduled for your case, you'll need to request cancellation of this when you provide details about your application.
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_STRIKE_OUT: Ask the court to strike out all or part of the other parties' case without a trial
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_SUMMARY_JUDGMENT: Ask the court to make a summary judgment on a case
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_SUMMARY_JUDGMENT_DESCRIPTION: This application should only be made if you do not believe the other parties' claim has any real prospect of success.
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_STRIKE_OUT_DESCRIPTION: This application should only be made if you believe that a document uploaded by the other parties, such as their defence, should be struck out as it has no real prospect of success.
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_VARY_JUDGMENT_DESCRIPTION: For example, if you want to request to pay a judgment amount in instalments or make a change to instalments you've already agreed. This application is usually made by defendants. Your payment offer will be presented to the other parties who can accept or reject it. If you're a defendant selecting this application, you'll need to upload an N245 form.
SELECT_TYPE.CAPTION: Make an application
SELECT_TYPE.NEED_MULTIPLE_APPLICATIONS: If you need to make multiple applications, you'll have the option to add another application later on.
SELECT_TYPE.SELECT_APPLICATION: Select the application you want and click continue.
SELECT_TYPE.TITLE: Select application
SELECT_TYPE.WHEN_YOU_REQUEST: When you request a change to your case, or contact the court to take a specific action, this is known as making an 'application' to the court for an order.
SELECT_TYPE.ASK_MORE_TIME_DESCRIPTION: For example, asking for the deadline for uploading documents before a trial or hearing to be extended. You'll need to provide a valid reason for not meeting the original deadline. This application can only be made before the original deadline has passed. This is also known as an application to extend time.  Instead of making an application, you can get written agreement from the other parties for more time to do what's required by the court. To do this, the time extension you request must be less than 28 days and should not affect a hearing date.
SELECT_TYPE.CONFIRM_YOU_PAID: Confirm you've paid a judgment (CCJ) debt
SELECT_TYPE.CONFIRM_YOU_PAID_DESCRIPTION: If you've paid the debt from a county court judgment (CCJ) in full, you can ask the court for proof of payment to share with banks, lenders and credit reference agencies. This is called requesting a certificate of cancellation or satisfaction.

SUMMARY.APP_REQUESTED: An application is a request for a change to the case.

ASK_FOR_PROOF_OF_DEBT_PAYMENT.PARA_1: If you've paid the debt from a county court judgment (CCJ), you can ask the court for proof of payment to share with banks and credit reference agencies. This is also known as requesting a certificate of cancellation or satisfaction.
ASK_FOR_PROOF_OF_DEBT_PAYMENT.PARA_2: The court fee for this is £{{ applicationFee }}. This fee will need to be paid once you've submitted your request. Find out if you can get
ASK_FOR_PROOF_OF_DEBT_PAYMENT.PARA_TITLE_1: If you paid within a month of the judgment
ASK_FOR_PROOF_OF_DEBT_PAYMENT.PARA_3: A certificate of cancellation can be requested if you have evidence that you paid the debt within one month of the date of judgment. This means the debt will be removed from the public register.
ASK_FOR_PROOF_OF_DEBT_PAYMENT.PARA_TITLE_2: If you paid after one month from the judgment
ASK_FOR_PROOF_OF_DEBT_PAYMENT.PARA_4: A certificate of satisfaction can be requested if the debt is paid after one month. The entry will remain on the public register for 6 years but will be marked 'satisfied'.
ASK_FOR_PROOF_OF_DEBT_PAYMENT.PARA_5: You must provide evidence that the debt has been paid in full. This should be confirmation from the person or business you owned money, which shows the:
ASK_FOR_PROOF_OF_DEBT_PAYMENT.PARA_TITLE_4: Agreement from the person or business owed money
ASK_FOR_PROOF_OF_DEBT_PAYMENT.PARA_6: Once you've made an application, the court will ask the person or business you owed money if they've been paid. If they don't respond within a month then the public register will be updated and a certificate issued.
ASK_FOR_PROOF_OF_DEBT_PAYMENT.PARA_7: If the person or business you owed money to does not agree, this case will move offline and the application will be considered by a district judge.
ASK_FOR_PROOF_OF_DEBT_PAYMENT.PARA_8: If your name or address have changed since the judgment (CCJ) was issued, you may want to update them before applying to confirm you've made a debt payment.
ASK_FOR_PROOF_OF_DEBT_PAYMENT.PARA_9: You will need to call the court where your judgment was issued to update the address we have for you. You can find the name of the court on the top right of
ASK_FOR_PROOF_OF_DEBT_PAYMENT.PARA_9_3: search for the contact details of the court.
ASK_FOR_PROOF_OF_DEBT_PAYMENT.PARA_9_4: This will be updated immediately and you can continue with your application.
ASK_FOR_PROOF_OF_DEBT_PAYMENT.PARA_10: If your name has changed since the judgment and you would like to update this, you'll need to make a
ASK_FOR_PROOF_OF_DEBT_PAYMENT.PARA_10_2: You will need to wait for the change to be completed before you can continue with your application.

FINAL_DEFENDANT_PAYMENT_DATE.TITLE: When was the final payment?
FINAL_DEFENDANT_PAYMENT_DATE.PARAGRAPH_TEXT_1: We need to know this to cancel the debt if you paid within one month or show
FINAL_DEFENDANT_PAYMENT_DATE.PARAGRAPH_TEXT_2: it as satisfied if you paid after one month.
FINAL_DEFENDANT_PAYMENT_DATE.FORM_HEADER_1: Enter the date of the final payment

SUBMIT_APPLICATION_OFFLINE.TITLE: Welsh Case
SUBMIT_APPLICATION_OFFLINE.SUMMARY: A party in this case has asked for their case documents to be in Welsh. For this reason, the case cannot proceed online and if you want to make an application to the court you must use the N244_LINK. There are guidance notes on the N244 page to help you fill in the form.

FINALISE_TRIAL_ARRANGEMENTS.IF_YOU_NEED_TO_MAKE_APPLICATION:
If you need to make an application, you must complete and submit your trial arrangements first. You should only make an application once this has been completed. There will be a link to make an application once you have finalised your trial arrangements.

If you make an application, please note the trial will go ahead as planned until the application is reviewed by a judge and an order made changing the date of the trial.
